title: Palpable Fibroadenoma in Young Woman
setup_script: A 22-year-old woman notes a 2 cm mobile, rubbery mass in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. She has no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Ultrasound shows a well-circumscribed, oval, hypoechoic mass.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Obtain history including duration, changes with menstrual cycle, and other symptoms; perform complete breast exam.
Order targeted breast ultrasound for young patients (<30 years) and avoid routine mammography due to dense tissue.
Interpret ultrasound findings consistent with fibroadenoma; discuss options of observation versus core needle biopsy.
If patient desires, perform ultrasound-guided core biopsy to confirm diagnosis and reassure the patient.
Explain natural history of fibroadenoma: may grow with hormones, often regress after menopause.
Discuss management: observation with repeat ultrasound in 6 months if lesion is classic; surgical excision if enlarging or symptomatic.
If excision chosen, plan outpatient surgery with small cosmetically placed incision; counsel about scar and rare recurrence.
Perform excisional biopsy; send for pathology to confirm fibroadenoma and rule out phyllodes tumor.
Postoperative care: manage wound, advise on activity restrictions; reassure patient about benign nature.
If pathology reveals phyllodes tumor, discuss need for wider excision and follow-up.
Educate patient on self-breast awareness and routine screening starting at age 40 or earlier if high risk.
Provide psychological support for anxiety related to breast lumps.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate use of imaging for young women with breast mass.
Distinguishing fibroadenoma from other lesions and deciding on biopsy versus observation.
Counseling on management options including excision and follow-up.
Ensuring complete excision if phyllodes tumor found.
Patient education about self-examination and screening.
